msItem.textLang: Possibly Goidelic written in OGHAM script

supportDesc.condition: A large irregularly shaped cave divided into two aisles by a rock buttress. The walls of the cave are full of natural fissures but also exhibit copious graffiti and carvings, including two ogham inscriptions. It is possible that letters have been lost from the beginning and end of the first inscription due to weathering (Forsyth 1996, 94-96).

layoutDesc.layout: The inscriptions are carved on the left-hand wall of the cave, about 2m above the present floor. The area is also decorated with a panel of snake-like, loose spiral interlace graffiti (Forsyth 1996, 94-5). The first inscription is about 9m and the second is about 11m from the entrance gate. Regarding the damaged sections of the first inscription, there is room for at least 6 letters at the beginning but only a few would fit in the space at the end.

handDesc.handNote: The stem line of the first inscription carved vertically between two patches of wear, the lower 260mm, the upper 84mm. Immediately after the end of the upper patch there is a clear cross-stroke where the stem appears to end. There is a potential similar stroke below the lower patch, but not absolutely clear. These two end-strokes are about 500mm apart. Nothing is visible in the upper patch of wear, in the lower there may be traces of occasional strokes, but these are very faint (Forsyth 1996, 94). In the central portion, between the areas of wear there are a series of fairly clear strokes between 30 and 40mm long that are carefully carved and neatly spaced.

history.provenance: Located in a sandstone cliff about 3km north of Blackwaterfoot are a series of caves of which the King's Cave at Drumadoon (Druim an Dúin 'ridge of the fort') is the largest. The walls of exhibit carvings which span from perhaps the Bronze Age to the present day. The animal and geometric carvings have been known since at least the end of the seventeenth century, but the presence of ogham was not noticed until about 1968 (Forsyth 1996, 94). The second ogham inscription, Blackwaterfoot2 (S-BUT-002), was not discovered until 1992 when Ian Fisher of the RCAHMS conducted further survey work on the cave (ibid.).
In situ. Kenneth Steer examined, measured, and drew the first inscription when he visited the cave in September 1971 (Forsyth 1996, 94).

app.note: Or in the unlikely event of the text being read downwards:

div.p: For the translation due to gaps caused by fissures and graffiti we only have the last two letters of the first name and at most the first name of the second. The MEQ may represent OIr. maicc (gen. of macc) which means 'son' (Forsyth 1996, 96).

As Forsyth observed (1996, 97), if the inscription is as late as the eighth century, the -eo could be the genitival ending of an i-stem personal name, eg. Fedlimd, Fedlimtheo. Alternatively, it could be the end of the nominative of a name such as Reo, Buaidbeo or one of the compounds with second element Nia/Nio, such as Flaithnia and Maicnio.

The inscription is an example of simple Type II inscriptions lacking the late features so they should be placed near the beginning of the Type II series. According to Forsyth, At best this would offer a relative date, but since simple Type II ogham continued in use alongside more ambitious, formal varieties of the script, inscriptions using this form cannot be closely dated. They could be as early as the Pool ogham (sixth century) or later than Dunadd (late eighth century?) (ibid. 99).

That the two ogham inscriptions, Blackwaterfoot 1 and Blackwaterfoot 2 (S-BUT-002), are contemporary with one another or with any other of the carvings in the cave cannot be proved (ibid. 95). However, it is clear that both are examples of casual graffiti.
